metadata./Title: AIRE mutation in an elderly Caroli’s patient with cholangitis and sepsis: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background Caroli’s disease, an autosomal recessive, hereditary-related disorder, is a rare disease, in which the diagnosis is based primarily on medical imaging and pathophysiological examinations. It is characterized by intrahepatic 
cystic dilation or cysts. Hepatic resection of diseased lobes can cure or avoid the risk of malignancy.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 65-year-old Asian man was admitted to our hospital with cholangitis and recurrent septicemia. 
The pathological diagnosis was polycystic bile duct dilation and cholangitis, consistent with the symptoms of Caroli’s 
disease. In addition, a genetic test report indicated that the autoimmune regulator (AIRE) gene had a c.275G > A variant (p. Arg92Gln hybrid mutation), which was different from the previously reported PKHD1 gene mutation in Caroli’s 
disease.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion This finding suggests that AIRE mutations may be associated with Caroli’s disease, with a risk of death 
and difficulty in curing.
Keywords  Caroli’s disease, Cholangitis, Septicemia, Genetic mutation, Case report
sections.Introduction:
Introduction
Caroli’s disease is characterized by congenital hepatic 
bile duct dilatation, and traffic spongiform hepatobiliary 
dilation is a type V in Alonso-Lej’s congenital gallbladder 
cysts [1]. Vechell and Stevens first reported the cases in 
1906 and 1939, respectively. The characteristic manifes tations were described in detail by Caroli et  al. in 1958 
[2]. It is an autosomal recessive genetic disease, and the 
gene involved is the same gene responsible for autoso mal recessive polycystic kidney disease. Caroli’s disease is usually codiagnosed by clinical imaging and genetic 
and histopathologic examination [1, 3]. Cystic expan sion of the gallbladder in the liver can increase the risk 
of malignant tumors by 100 times [4]. Fatality rates are 
closely associated with complications, such as combining 
infections and malignant outcomes. Patients always have 
unexplained upper abdominal pain or hepatic fibrosis. 
Current therapy options for Caroli’s disease mainly target 
complications but do not prevent disease progression [5]. 
It has been reported that there are no gender differences. 
Epidemiological studies have shown that it is always 
found in children and adolescents and is more common 
in people of Asian descent [6].
In the case reported in this study, the patient was 
treated for limb weakness and abdominal pain and was 
eventually diagnosed with Caroli’s disease by combining 
magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

have been few reports of a link between Caroli’s disease 
and mutations in the AIRE gene.
A 65-year-old Asian man experienced limb weakness, 
yellow urine, and right upper abdominal pain in the past 
1  month. MRI examination suggests cirrhosis, multi ple hepatic cysts, and very low right lower renal density. 
After receiving anti-inflammatory and hepatic support ive treatment at his hometown hospital, his symptoms 
improved, and he was discharged (30 March 2021). 
He had recurrent symptoms of aggravated limb sore ness and fatigue, inadequate food intake, poor sleep at 
night, but he no fever, no chest tightness or shortness of 
breath, no obvious phlegm cough, no hematemesis, no 
clay-colored stools, no skin itching, nosebleeds, bleed ing gums, no abdominal pain, and no progressive weight 
loss. To further clarify the cause of cirrhosis, he went to 
the designated outpatient clinic of our hospital and was 
hospitalized for “cirrhosis. ” The patient had a history of 
hypertension for many years, the blood pressure was 
160/100 mmHg, amlodipine was taken to control blood 
pressure, and no antihypertensive tablets were taken 
for nearly half a month. The patient developed cerebral 
infarction and had recently taken bucphenylphthalein 
softgels and rosuvastatin calcium tablets. At the time 
of admission to our hospital (April 21, 2021), the physi cal examination showed that the patient was in a good 
mental state; he had a dark complexion, chronic hepatic 
disease appearance, clear breathing sounds in both lungs, 
flat abdomen, no compressive pain, anti-bouncing pain, 
and no pain in the gallbladder area, and he had a negative 
Murphy sign.
The physical examination and initial vital signs dur ing hospitalization were as follows: the patient’s body 
temperature was 38.5–39.2  ℃, and he had feelings of 
dizziness, fatigue, fearless chills, no sputum cough, no 
abdominal pain and diarrhea, and no urinary frequency 
and urgency, etc. He was instructed to take ibupro fen to cool down and drink more water, and his blood 
counts, procalcitonin levels, and a blood culture were 
taken. During treatment, the cultures were repeatedly 
positive for E. coli, and the body temperature was con tinuously increased, accompanied by runny nose, occa sional cough, no sputum, no chest tightness, no nausea 
and vomiting, and no abdominal pain or diarrhea. The 
red blood count increased to 58.0/mL (normal value: 
0–17/mL) and the serum direct bilirubin increased to 
8.2 mol/L (normal value: 0–5.1 μmol/L). His hepatitis E 
virus IgG antibody was positive and his antinuclear fac tor was weakly positive. The hepatitis B antigen, hepatitis 
C antigen, and butyl hepatitis antigen was negative. His 
reticulocytes increased to 141.50 ×  109/L (normal value: 
34.6–100 ×  109/L), hemoglobin decreased to 113 g/L (nor mal value: 130–175  g/L), lymphocyte count decreased to 0.49 ×  109/L (normal value: 1.10–3.20 ×  109/L), and 
procalcitonin increased to 0.49  ng/mL (normal value: 
0–0.05  ng/mL). These results indicated an acute phase 
of anemia, infectious diseases and sepsis. Furthermore, 
hepatic function examination showed impaired hepatic 
function. The patient was treated with piperacillin tazo bactam anti-infection therapy, inosine glucose, and glu tathione injections to protect the detoxification functions 
of the liver and kidneys, and he continued silybin glucose 
meglucomonium to protect liver function, buccinthal ide softgels to treat cerebral infarction, rosuvastatin cal cium to reduce cholesterol, Anluo chemical fiber pills 
to prevent liver fibrosis, and tamsulosin hydrochloride 
extended-release capsules to prevent prostatic hyperpla sia. Gram-negative bacilli were identified in the blood of 
the patient, it is a multidrug-resistant bacterium and this 
infection was treated with penicillin antibacterial. Dur ing the period of treatment accompanied by low blood 
potassium, potassium chloride extended-release tablets 
and intravenous potassium supplementation were given. 
As shown in Fig.  1A, the MRI examination image showed 
that the gallbladder was dilated, with multiple small cysts 
in the liver, accompanied by an abnormal density of the 
right posterior lobe of the liver, which was considered 
a high probability of being an infectious lesion. Finally, 
hepatic tissue biopsy was used to diagnose hematoma 
lesions, cirrhosis, and hepatic cysts.
The expression of cytokeratin 7 (CK7) and cytokera tin 20 (CK20) could help to establish the origin of the 
biliary tract [7]. Anti-CK7 and CK18 antibodies are also 
used for immunochemical analysis of catheter plate mal formations [8]. We investigated the expression of CK7 
in CK18 for bile duct staining in the hepattic tissues of 
patients with Caroli’s disease. Compared with the stand ard hepatic tissue control in Fig.  1B and C, the patient’s 
hepatic fibrosis stage (S) and necroinflammatory activ ity grade (G) were histopathologically determined. His 
hepatic fibrosis reached G3S4. Cirrhosis of the liver may 
be found as pseudolobullar and hepatocyte-like bal looning degeneration (Fig.  1D). Figure  1E and F show 
that the appearance of the cholangeal plate malforma tion was accompanied by fibroblast proliferation. The 
patient’s first hospitalization was positive for Escherichia 
coli in the blood. Pathological tests showed positive neu trophils in the bile ducts (Fig.  1F). According to Fig.  1G, 
the plasma cells  (CD38+ and MUM-1+) embedded in the 
patient’s hepatic tissue indicated hepatitis. Positive fer rum (FER) staining in the hepatic tissue (FER+) indicated 
a risk of secondary cirrhosis and inflammatory necrosis. 
Given that the patient’s fever, abdominal pain, and patho logical characteristics may be associated with Caroli’s 
disease-related infections, anti-infective treatment alle viated the concomitant disease, and the patient could be

discharged. Follow-up studies found that the patient had 
secondary sepsis and fever recurrence one week after dis charge, followed by MRI and genetic testing in Shanghai. 
After testing, the blood gene results did not report the 
PKHD1 gene mutations that commonly occur in Caro li’s disease but rather an abnormality in the AIRE gene. 
Possible pathogenic variants were reported in the AIRE 
gene (NM_000383.4): c.275G > A, p. Arg92Gln at chro mosomal position Chr21 (GRCh37): g.45706582G > A, 
with hybrid mutation (detected by Shanghai Jiao Tong 
University Hospital). The patient’s blood sample showed 
the c.275G > A, p. Arg92Gln mutation, which was not 
included in the database of controlled populations such 
as Genome Aggregation Database ( GnomAD). The 
molecular genetic diagnosis of the patient that was made 
by the hospital was concluded based on the literature: 
AIRE gene mutation can cause autoimmune polyendo crine syndrome and other diseases, which can manifest 
as autosomal dominant or recessive inheritance. The 
pathogenic conclusion of the genetic variant needs to be combined with the clinical phenotype for further diag nosis. The patient denied that his parents had a related 
congenital disorder. Combined with our pathological 
diagnosis and MRI imaging examination in our hospi tal, it was judged as Caroli’s disease. The patient was fol lowed for 7 months, as evidenced by improved nutrition 
as required by his doctor and regular abdominal pain epi sodes every three months.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Caroli’s disease, also known as traffic spongiform bile 
duct dilation or communicating bile duct cysts, needs 
to be identified as congenital hepatic fibrosis due to the 
overlap between clinical manifestations and pathologi cal patterns and congenital hepatic fibrosis [1, 9]. Most 
patients show mixed symptoms; the typical clinical mani festations are abdominal pain, jaundice, and abdominal 
lump triple; and there may be no specific early clinical 
manifestations or no apparent symptoms [3, 9]. Most 
patients who are diagnosed with Caroli’s disease are

diagnosed before the age of 50 or even around the age 
of 10 [5, 6]. Usually, patients with a first diagnosis are 
mainly children and adolescents [10]. Because the disease 
will appear malignant and belongs to a genetic disease 
and clinical rare disease, and there is no better conserva tive treatment, most patients will choose liver transplant 
treatment at a younger age. The main basis for diagnos ing the disease is imaging examination, genetic history, 
and hepatic pathological examination, and the pathologi cal diagnosis is considered to be the gold standard for its 
diagnosis [9, 11, 12]. Caroli’s disease is rarely detected at 
an advanced age, its progression and prognosis may dif fer from those at a young age, and the relevant induction 
mechanisms and effective interventions are yet to be fur ther studied.
The AIRE gene is crucial for establishing central immu nological tolerance and preventing autoimmunity, and 
mutations in AIRE cause rare autosomal-recessive dis ease [13]. The case has not been reported locally and is 
the case of a 65-year-old male patient with no family his tory, with severe pathological manifestations of hepatic 
fibrosis and cirrhosis (G3S4), accompanied by repeated 
bile cholangitis and intrablood E. coli infection. The 
results of its genetic examination are different from pre vious reports, and the genetic mutations provided by Li 
et al. [9] were PKD1  genes: c.7670A > G, chr16:2156125, 
p.D2557G. Hence, specific genetic evidence is not avail able, and the genetic information provided in this study 
may provide a reference for future diagnosis.
Conclusion
This finding suggests that AIRE mutations may be asso ciated with Caroli’s disease, with a risk of death and dif ficulty in curing.
